---


**Confidence interval (CI)** - a statistical estimate
- Introduced in [[Topics/Mathematics/Statistics and probabilities/Statistics/Statistics|Statistics]] in a **1937** paper by **Jerzy Neyman**, and slowly adopted...
- gives a ==range of values== for an unknown parameter (eg. a population mean) estimated from a (random) sample
- a higher **confidence level** (chosen by the investigator) (tend to?) lead to a wider/less precise **confidence interval**
- Most commonly, a **95% confidence level** is used
- Calculations
	- $\text{Best estimate} \pm \text{Margin of error (MOE)}$ 
	- $\text{margin of error}=z\times \text{estimated standard error (SE)}$
	- $SE=\sqrt{\frac{p_1(1-p_1)}{n}}$

---
### z-score/p-value
-> https://pro.arcgis.com/fr/pro-app/2.8/tool-reference/spatial-statistics/what-is-a-z-score-what-is-a-p-value.htm

---
### Applications
> Very important in Statistics & Machine Learning
- Surveys
- Medical research / Pharmacy => for FDA regulation
- ...

### Examples
- Comment savoir si un échantillon est statistiquement représentatif ?
	- fiabilité d'un sondage

---
### See also
- Error bar : 
- **68–95–99.7** rule (aka. the **empirical rule**, the **three-sigma** rule of thumb)
	- in *social sciences* $2\sigma$ can be enough, and in *particle physics* $5\sigma$ (99.99994)
- [[Topics/Mathematics/People/Ronald Fisher|Ronald Fisher]] introduced : p-value, hypothesis testing, null hypothesis, ...
- There are *==several ways to calculate the **CI**==* :
	- **(normalized) z-score** (if sample size is large & you know the population standard deviation)
		- *"==estimate of the number of standard deviations== that an observation lies from the mean"*
		- alpha level = 1 - confidence level (0.95)?
	- **t-score** (if small sample size & unknown population variance)
	- the **z statistic**
		- => use a Z score table to find the resulting **interval**
